_mLTuqruTFXLQKKAiOIuZA.text: The Salt Yard and sister restaurant Dehesa are two of my favourite fancy schmancy tapas places. Without fail, I order myself some fantastic courgette flowers (who knew they could be so good!) and one of their cheese plates along with a nice big glass of red wine. It's one of those places I go if I want to know that I won't be disappointed in the food or the service, which is a great combo when you're feeling indecisive about where to go for food. Plus, the atmosphere is welcoming and relaxed enough that I could sit all night ordering more plates.

XlD6VrHyblQqP0RI5zE22Q.text: Really good food and wine list is good too. Pork belly and salt cod and cheese board fantastic!!!

ovEJAcQmV1JbENLnO70k-w.text: Great food, in a tight, noisy place with good, friendly atmosphere and lots of energy. In summer can get tables (4) outside. Good wine list, interesting food: tapas size dishes but with a wider influence than spain. Go and try!

_swRS2GlRU5vxfN-3PGWQg.text: The best place I have been to for tapas, this restaurant is wonderful. A small space upstairs, with additional seating downstaris, you should come with a good appetite. I try and experience new and different tastes and this tapas bar certainly delivers. From the truffle honey with cheese and bread through the cheese stuffed aubergine flowers to the excellent wine selection, this food is great. The staff are helpful and ready and able to aid with your food choise based on what flavours you enjoy. I have been to this restaurant secveral times and I have never had a bad dish. I would highly recommend this place.

9CW2w7jJ_OxQ2_N4q21IBg.text: A fantastic spot for my office's informal Second Christmas Lunch, Salt Yard treated my colleagues and me to rich, gorgeous tapas, friendly service,  and a lovely atmosphere. The food was really, really terrific. Just wonderful. Rich, flavourful, diverse, exotic, and truly delicious. To be honest, we were glad that we didn't follow the "2-3 plates per person, plus patatas fritas, bread and ailoi, tortillas, olives and other nibbles for the table" recommendation for sharing, because we would have had absolutely no hope for rolling ourselves back to the office and getting our last bits of work done. We each ordered one or two plates--the Monte Enebro cheese-stuffed courgette flowers drizzled with honey and the chorizo were the absolute stars of the meal--plus tortillas, etc, and sent them round for sharing. There is an excellent mix of items on the menu, from the lovely-and-accessible grilled tiger prawns or lemon rosemary roasted chicken breast, all the way to the thrillingly-exotic stuffed baby squid with fennel or baby violet artichokes with pine nut puree. Everything I had was truly excellent, and I would auction off my first born for another serving of the stuffed courgette flowers. The server was friendly, patient, knowledgeable, and happy to help with suggestions and wine parings. For a decently large party peppered with picky eaters and tapas novices she was an absolute star in helping us get precisely what we wanted, and each of us walked away happy, relaxed, and full to the point of bursting. The only very small gripe any of us had with the meal was the space afforded to our party. There were, I believe, 9 of us, and we were seated at a corner booth that should have comfortably seated 6 or so. We were able to cram in just fine and it turned out to be far less of an imposition than it had initially appeared, but if we'd been allotted just a slightly bigger table the experience would have bordered on 5-star.

8FzhPrkBIfMJBTt6XPeryw.text: I had lunch here today. We let the waitress choose all our dishes. Loved it. 5 stars and I wasn't even drinking.

oTUDN5DGTv17PB_X6S3KqQ.text: I finally found my 1991 Chateau Breoun Cab-Sav here last night. Ahhh, the sovereign wine of my late youth, warmed my senses with memories and warm feelings of my Mum and family. My palette was equally pleased with the aromas flavors. What an inspirational little wine and food pub. Loved the liberal wine selection and the

uhwqQi-DSN35gsmyLpkHzA.text: Full review and photos on thehappinessprojectlondo…  The Salt Yard is sort of posh Spanish tapas, with charcuterie platters as well as hot plates, and the food was pretty awesome. We ordered a glass of Selva Capuzza (Groppello, Lake Garda 2009) (not picked by me but amaaazing, £6.50 each) and tucked into the delicious-sounding menu  they suggest about 3 plates each. We had the Spanish charcuterie board which was perfect with the wine and very nom, and the Courgette Flowers stuffed with Goats Cheese in a light batter and a wonderful honey sauce which were just mouth-watering. And then Jamon Croquetas with Manchego which were light and delicious too. And then the big guns  the delicious Salt Marsh Lamb with Cipollini Onions, Wet Garlic and Fennel Pickle which was mouth-wateringly tender and just YUM and then Chargrilled Bavette with Pumpkin Caponata, Shallots and Crispy Bone Marrow which was cooked wonderfully rare and juicy and was probably my favourite dish and finally the Crispy Squid with Sea Purslane and Shellfish Alioli which was delicate and light and crispy. The menu is bloody brilliant, we kept stopping to nod and mumble praise at each plate, and I'd like to go back to try other things like the pork belly and chorizo with peppers. So we then had another glass of wine because it was just THAT GOOD it would be rude not to, and left feeling warm and happy for the rest of the afternoon. We both agreed it was a spectacular lunch  beautifully cooked, interesting and delicious. The downside was that it ain't cheap - for 2 glasses of wine each, a huge lunch and 2 coffees, it was just under £100 or £50 each and just popping in to sit at the bar to have a glass of wine and charcuterie board to share (which looks ace) would set you back at least £30 each I reckon. But I wasn't paying so it was all good. And although I wouldn't make it a regular lunch venue at that price, for a special-ish occasion, it would be the perfect place to take your best mate / mum / beloved for lunch or a wine-and-charcuterie snack, like after Christmas shopping in town. Yes, for me shopping is a special occasion. Alternatively, do like the HPL and wangle an invite for a free lunch.

A2TT6RHN8EUvThFddqEauw.text: Superb service, not over baring, and very helpful, the wine recommendations were terrific and not overly priced. The food is fantastic. Amazing scallops, cheese and meats. A great setting for long boozy lunches or dinner with a gang of friends.

4KNtWsiHkaQQ47e9s5MZjQ.text: How easy is it to write reviews of places where the food is this good?! The problem is, how to remember all the amazing dishes you've had. My first visit to this fantastic Tapas, Charcuterie and wine bar was for a sit-down tapas meal at lunchtime with some colleagues. We selected a decent array of dishes but we had to order more Pork Belly (Confit of 'Gloucester Old Spot' Pork Belly with rosemary scented cannelini beans) because we ended up fighting over it. It was incredible. As were all the other dishes of course but this was a definite favourite. I ended up coming back the next week just to try some more! Subsequent visits have not disappointed either. The fish selections are first-rate with the Smoked Monkfish (Smoked Monkfish with Gooseberry Puree and Pancetta) and the scallops (Sauteed Scallops with Romanesque Puree & PX Caramel) really standing out. This is also one of those tapas restaurants where vegetarians can also expect to leave satisfied with the non-meat options. Items such as the Stuffed Cougette flowers and the sautéed Girolles sure to excite even the most carnivorous members of your group. Finally, the upstairs area also serves as a very pleasant wine bar with it's own bar snacks menu. Surely any place that boasts quails' eggs and acorn-fed Iberico ham as 'bar snacks' has got to be worth a visit.

vbv2kYQi5-cCrGANUmIcgg.text: From the outside Salt Yard looks fairly nice - nice décor, fairly intimate and dark, and modern. The service was pretty good with our Aussie waiter fairly attentive and friendly when we needed him but otherwise was welcomingly absent for the rest of the night (it was a pleasure not to feel too much pressure to leave once we'd finished eating.) Unfortunately the food was a bit of a let down and very pricey. The menu is apparently constantly changing. Everything was presented beautifully except for the strangely barren Chorizo. Ironically the most simply presented (the Courgette Flowers, Squid and Chorizo) were definitely the tastiest dishes whilst the dishes with the more complicated presentation (the Beef and Salmon) were disappointingly tasteless. Portion-wise I guess with tapas you can expect to eat quite a few dishes to get your fill and I was just glad that we'd had a gigantic lunch so I was feeling adequately satisfied sharing the above with Sandra. Salt Yard for me was just okay.

VH54mYdsASgfskuom47R-g.text: Fantastic tapas restaurant. Really enjoyed all of the dishes--buffalo, chicken, duck, squid, truffled mac and cheese, assorted cheeses, olives, among others that I can't quite recall because I went a couple of weeks ago--all divine. Extensive wine list. Great waitstaff.

OzECtQHEHSGuWBE3dX4-0Q.text: OK Tapas. I've had better in the city tho.

hZ_MwvXGQNcJcOIATY0Niw.text: Each time I go I love the food, no nonsense service and good value.

6KqZ352GsbqT0TM5To7JMw.text: Mrs Cheesemonger and I Ioved this place so much on our last trip to London that we ate here twice.

e-rvWBFkd-FC5mss9IKEwQ.text: What a great spot!  We sat at the bar and got great service and help with wine from the bartender.  The goat cheese platter had some excellent choices and it paired nicely with the Spanish charcuterie platter. Make sure to get the grilled bread to go with your cheeses.  Such a nice break from all of the pub food we encounted on our trip.  If I'm ever back to visit London again, I will definitely eat here!

yXba6Enznsq5rA7NO7Miaw.text: It was one rainy evening we were tired and hungry and we saw this cozy and lovely looking restaurant, we did not think twice before we stepped in.The man sitting on the next table was eating some incredible looking tiger prawn tapas and he laugh when he noticed our hungry looking eyes staring his plate. After that we could not but order the same dish, accompanied with a cheese plate and two big classes of red wine to warm us up.The cheese was divine but just served with a tiny piece of bread. We had to ask some more, which they charged separately, of course. Also the dishes were really tiny, even for tapas, and still priced like a main dishes. This just left us feeling like it wasn't completely money worth and that we could have had a proper meals with the same price.

X_12Tw69p9_EP-zUDI3gQA.text: Recommended by a friend and did not fail to deliver. Low key, but cool decor. Exceptionally friendly service and great twists on tapas classics. 3 dishes pet person is plenty and the cheeses and meats are fantastic. Recommended wine was perfect accompaniment. Hard to fault and a rare 10/10 find in an otherwise indifferent London restaurant scene.

zQZlwKRbSVX--y_KhxyMSA.text: Saltyard is a Goodge Street haven for people with decent palates. I still dream about the courgette flowers stuffed with goats cheese and drizzled with truffle honey (around £4 per portion). Don't worry, there is a huge choice for meat-lovers as well, and an extensive cheese board to top up your cholesterol count. Needless to say, I can't afford to eat here very often, one gets carried away with the sheer choice on offer, and it's easy to go over budget with the decadence of it all. I've been here twice, and both times I've left with an incredibly full tummy. Each dish costs around £3-8.

L9w0Hgm4OrOdlkVYtQMBjg.text: I Love Spanish food and red wine. The Salt Yard offers excellant examples of both. Served in daintey portions the food is very fresh and tasty. We enjoyed scollops, asparigas and cheese flowers, pepper squid with aioli, tuna capachio. My advise would be to book as you can wait a long time for a table upstairs - they are fully booked most of time, the tables upstairs are seated on a first come basis. A little pricey so I would not descibe this as a cheap date - dinner for 2 with one bottle of wine and 2 extra glasses just short of £100. But great food none the less.

AFg4uqy90txP-m0TGDZSGQ.text: One of the best tapas restaurants in London, if not THE best. Every dish that I have ever tried has been delicious, and I still salivate over the aubergine flowers. Tapas is really hard to do, and Salt Yard appears to get it right every time. Great wine selection too.

3JTd32KDJm6RoutPN6chPQ.text: Better for a big group on a big night than for an intimate gathering or a quick bite. This place has a fine tapas selection but it's hard to justify the pricesvery attentive staff though. And as always with tapas, it's all about the bravas ;-)

gm4i_Ej3QlRGV1EtXL3YEw.text: We popped in on a whim Friday night around 7pm and though the restaurant was packed we were happy/surprised to be told they would be able to seat our group of four between 7-8pm. We gave our (US) mobile phone # to the lovely gentleman who greeted us, then went down the street for cocktails. He called us on our mobile (called us internationally, in fact) when the table was clearing, and we popped right over. We waited exactly as long as it takes my boozer friends to consume a single cocktail!I love tapas and was so excited to have landed in a Michelin-starred restaurant in London! While the gent at the door was delightful, our server was not. We ate and drank enormous amounts, and were the easiest customers she could have as we love to eat everything, so all she had to do was bring us food, but her attitude implied she was above her role. That didn't stop us from literally eating almost everything on the menu, including two nice bottles of wine, dessert, cheese course and digestifs. Despite the amount of food we ordered, I didn't leave feeling grotesquely full (whatever that means; either we didn't get enough to eat or I ordered the proper amount for a change?)A couple of the dishes were Delicious, but for the most part, our group compared the restaurant to other far-flung tapas restaurants (Chicago -- Azucar, Las Ramblas, and obviously many in Spain) that were actually as delicious if not more so......without the Michelin to hang their hats on.Obviously more pricey, it was still a great night out and wonderful memory of one of the many dining experiences we had most recently in London.

a3GE-xO12L1Ju8TsfnBVFw.text: On a particularly rainy night and with no definite dinner plans, we wandered close to our hotel, and explored the myriad dining establishments along Goode St.  Having read about Salt Yard, we decided to go in and try our luck.  As with our experience at Polpo, we were greeted very warmly by the host, and given a very detailed assessment of the seating situation and wait time.  We said yes, after we saw the scrumptious dishes on the tables, and how everyone seemed to be having a great time.To start, a bottle of 2009 Macia Batle Rosado, made of Mantonegro and Callet from Mallorca.  A great crisp light wine.  It was rainy and cold outside, but warm and inviting in the small dining room inside.  The rose was perfect.  Also always great to learn about unfamiliar grape varietals.  Highlight of the meal was the Confit of Glouster Old Spot Pork Belly with Rosemary Scented Cannellini Beans.  This was my favorite dish of this trip to London.  The cube of meat stood about a good 3 inches high.  The top layer of skin was absolutely crunchy.  The meat on all sides was nicely seared and crispy.  Inside was melt-in-your-mouth tenderness.  I'd say a marvel of culinary engineering on how the whole thing was cooked.  The accompanying cannellini beans had just the right texture, with a very inviting scent of rosemary.  It is definitely something I will attempt to try at home.  Other highlights included Courgette Flowers stuffed with Goats Cheese, drizzled with Honey; Trevise Salad with Orange, Fresh Peas, and Radish; Chargrilled Bavette with Crispy Violet Artichokes, Shallots, and Horseradish.  I'm always skeptical about zucchini flower preparations.  The slightest heavy hand on the stuffing can cross the line to overpowering the delicate flower.  This version was great, the goat cheese provided a very light, creamy textural contrast to the crispy batter.  I was also unfamiliar with the drizzle of honey.  It worked here, again, giving the dish a new dimension.  The bavette was nicely grilled, just a tad before medium rare.  I like fried artichoke preparations, and this one did not disappoint.  For the salad, the genius combination screamed fresh.  A great dish after all the richness of the meat and fried food.For a great finale, a Buttermilk Panacotta with Roasted Figs, Saba and Madeline.  The use of buttermilk gave the custard a nice tanginess.  The figs, and the saba (grape syrup) put the sweetness right back into the dish, but in an utterly delicious way.  This was also, in this trip, the best 'pudding' I've had.Why 5 stars?  Super friendly and efficient staff.  Great little dining room.  Inventive use of ingredients.  Great flavor combination.  I picked both a savory, and sweet dish from Salt Yard as my favorites on this London trip.  Just absolutely brilliant.

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Glouster Old Spot and canellini beans

-4l5Mj0T4lcuixDX6Rp5uQ.text: Such great tapas! Though the owners have also opened Dehesa, it is still Salt Yard that I prefer. Intimate setting with great selection of wine and food with awesome service - what's not to like? Highly recommended are the courgette flowers, the pork belly and the croquettes. The waiters have great knowledge of the wine list, and will definitely recommend the best one to go with your meal!

C3KNzHWaVKOQ4D3ABwqsAg.text: If it were possible to give 3.5 stars, I would have opted for that, but seeing as I'm in a generous mood, 4 it is!  1 star for the friendly service1 star for the jamon iberico (YUM) and crusty, grilled bread1 star for the quail which was tender and juicy1/2 star for the rocket, radicchio, walnut and gorgonzola salad which was pretty tasty, but a tad over dressed for my liking1/2 star for the glass of vermentino and respectable wine listThe arctic char dish was a bit overcooked, but the mushrooms were tasty.  And the tuna carpaccio was too salty, but I liked the baby beans and salsa verde.  Seeing as my company has an office near the restaurant, I could see myself going again, but with the plethora of choices in the Goodge/Charlotte Street area, I'd probably opt for something else first.

CPoVth3kiKuqJn21NWjTzQ.text: The food deserves. 5 stars... The portions 1 star. We were 4 people and most bite size tapas had 3 pieces each? How are we meant to share 3 scallops 4-ways? We actually cheered when they brought us some plates with 4 pieces, such as the chorizo. Excellent food with beautiful flavours. Shame about the portions. The staggering of the tapas (they came out one by one) was good for stalling our appetite, but those earlier ones sure disappeared fast! Except for the bread. At £1 per half slice... It's a bit ridiculous. I'm sure they could have spared a 4th half slice at least. (again the 3-piece portions! Puzzling!) I think i would go back. Dessert was delicious, and saved us from walking away hungry despite a meal for 4 (without the drinks) setting us back £140. Not a restaurant to walk into feeling ravenous. Save that for Relais de Venise or Gaucho...

KFtBJDKD6f55zwrsfybsvw.text: We arrived with a party of six and the place was very busy. Understandably, they were unable to seat us. They offered to make a booking for us later in the evening, and we returned after an hour at the appointed time. When we arrived (even hungrier than before) we were informed that they gave away our table to "a man who looked like you."  Not a good impression of this restaurant's professionalism. Be prepared to get turned away even if you make a booking.

RKv0-V84PUAe7sUZKoKYzg.text: Cozy, two-level space (ground floor is better than basement level). No tables available for walk-ins on this rainy Saturday night, but the bar had space and comfy bar stools with padded backs. Good value glass of red wine (£3.75) and a bottle of good Italian beer, and we were happy already. We decided to pick one plate each from the fish, meat and vegetable sections and were pleasantly surprised by all our selections: roasted sea bream with saffron mash and marinated squid in a delicious broth, chargrilled venison haunch with beetroot and a caper/anchovy dressing, and fried violet artichokes with pine nut puree. These are not your usual tapas! Will try the charcuterie plate next time; they had a proper meat slicer and everything. Bill came to about £30 for our three tapas, wine and beer. Service at the bar was friendly and attentive, not pushy at all. Did I need a £1 Tesco sandwich later on? Sure, but we're not rich! Will go back -- to Salt Yard, I mean. Well, Tesco too. Good place to bring friends, too (Salt Yard, not Tesco).

U7-aQ3ZA5rX8OS-RY83_Ag.text: For really good affordable tapas you really can't go past Salt Yard (Goodge St Tube). It is an award-winning bar and restaurant serving modern tapas inspired by the flavours and produce of Spain and Italy. The tapas are complemented by charcuterie and cheese boards. But if you find yourself more central, head to it's lovely sister restaurant- Dehesa- in Ganton Street, Soho. Dehesa is the unique woodland area in Spain which is home to the black-footed Iberico pigs- said to produce the best ham in the world.

_Cwf5SN5ee2EA5MBr5Aq6Q.text: Firstly Superb food! Took a good client here for a meal. Bit last minute so had to sit upstairs. However this wasn't a problem. Service really good. We asked the waiter to select our food and he did not let us down. Courgette flowers so many people say about.... Now I know why.... Good food, good atmosphere and priced reasonably for the quality you get.

5yeCrQOOkYy2oLtd_4HWHQ.text: Who doesn't love a tasty tidbit?  Nice little gem of a restaurant will lots of lovely choices for bits and bobs and libations.

O7oVXV_VoMk_OIbjyjsAfA.text: Yum yum yum this place is good!I took my girlfriend here the other day for a birthday lunch because I'd been recommended it numerous times on Twitter.For the first time this year it was warm enough to sit outside and dine alfresco! Seeing as it felt like we were on holiday we grabbed some light bites to tie us over until dinner.We shared a platter of cured meats, bowl of mixed olives and a basket of char grilled soft bread with olive oil dip. To drink, I had a beer and my girlfriend had a Belini cocktail.The service was absolutely spot on, the food was gorgeous and the alfresco people watching was entertaining. Although a little pricey, this place is good, and well recommended!

ZajeQtW4PNa2ZfzaCdBBUA.text: Truffle honey + cheese = they will have to kick me out. Lots of interesting choices & great wine list. Would get 5 stars if they'd add more healthy options.

v4e1PaTRHNSLUWGEwgSnbg.text: Had a good time with a friend and real fun. We were pleasently surprised by the food here, not really bad.

mHaqsNUeejUC29B01ZLcAA.text: A disappointing experience but fabulous food. But how can that happen? My wife and I booked a table through saltyard.co.uk online for 7.00 pm last Saturday evening. We specifically let it be known that we would dine on tapas and requested a RESTAURANT table in a separate e-mail. When we arrived promptly at 7.00 pm we were told that the restaurant in the basement was fully booked - it had been allocated to 6.00 pm reservations. The basement restaurant actually looked very nice and would have been most acceptable. However, we had to make do with the ground floor bar, which I would describe as an uncomfortable, cramped but up-market snack bar, where diners may sit on bar stools or small tables to dine on gourmet bar snacks, charcuterie and fine wines. We were there for the much trumpeted RESTAURANT tapas and fine wine, not the snacks. We were very disppointed that we had not neen advised in advance that a table in the restaurant would be unavailable. One of the staff had telephoned me earlier at 3pm to request confirmation that we would arrive at 7pm, so there was no excuse for the absence of honest, couteous communication. Perhaps management correctly guess that people in my situation would normally cancel the reservation and dine elsewhere. I've been running my own business for many years so I'm naturally cynical. The small cramped tables along the wall facing the bar were awful. They are small, but worse still - there is not much space between them, so at a busy time like Saturday evening there is no privacy. We could hear our neighbours conversations on both sides. We ordered fantastic chargrilled bread with dips and just 6 tapas dishes to share. The tapas were delicious and from a quality (but not quantity) angle fully deserve the five star rating given by TimeOut. If it is possible to have a least favourite dish at the Salt Yard, it would be the potato and ham croquetas for me. The tapas portions were much smaller than I'm used to seeing, especiially the courgettes and chargrilled chorizo dishes. We also had the Classic Tortilla (which was the most substantial dish), the delicious spring chicken and a lovely Terise salad. At £22 the bottle, the Spanish red wine was superb. The staff were professional and helpful - they deserved the 12.5% service charge which is automatically added to the bill. Given the uncomfortable cramped conditions and that we were paying restaurant prices for sitting in a glorified snack bar, the food does not provide value for money. After ordering the food and wine my wife headed downstairs to the Ladies. Annoyingly she slipped on a wet floor on the way in and fell on her knee. Fortunately there was no damage, she was sober and she is lightweight and agile. If she had been tipsy, overweight and unfit, the accident could have been very nasty indeed. More attention to customer safety is required. We each had a quick espresso coffee, paid the bill (seventy something pounds) and left at 8.15 pm. We were actually allowed to stay until 9.00 pm and under normal circumstances I would have ordered perhaps two more tapas dishes, possibly cheese and/or puddings too. However I was frankly glad to get out of the place and will never go back. If it wasn't for the superb quality of the food and wine I would be giving this restaurant/snack bar the lowest rating of just 1 star. Zero marks for the management.

thVMe-E5Ac94pwLaLXBD2g.text: A pleasant well-cooked suprise!  Tapas in London - and no chips.  Smiling service, if not just a tad exhausted, and to-die-for ravioli, pork belly and lightly accented Italian staff.  A British couple sat next to us whose combined ass span was 6 feet,  so we guarded our glasses when they laughed, but otherwise i'd return for more prosciutto - but pick your seats well and avoid the dungeon table next to the loo and big-assed couples.Mainehigh: 4

w3Kk4GQxrmOcW8QfQod6jw.text: Salt Yard is a restaurant and bar that specialize in Spanish and Italian Tapas. They have the most amazing wine list and the waiters are very knowledgeable, so if you go don't hesitate to ask what wine they recommend going with your meal. Salt Yard is run by the same people that have Blackfoot Butchers just around the corner so you know where the meat in your plate comes from. They make a special dish every month so check out what the new dish is before ordering, its always working with seasonal produce to ensure the best quality, and it shows.

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom

P8ruxk3rkHj_1iRC8JjT2Q.text: Fun tapas bar. Had a great time with my friends. I definitely recommend a reservation if you want to go. Loved the food! Everything I tried was delicious. Loved the wine selection!My only complaint is that they do not give you enough bread. The bread portions are extremely small. Else I would have given it 5 stars.

UiK9taB74kLmS9tjogaEAg.text: Before I start, I should probably say I wasn't in a Salt Yard kind of mood. At all. I've been once before about 4 years ago so had thought it was time for a return visit. But after a ridiculously annoying day dealing with a boiler that suddenly went kaput - and then an insane rigmarole with British Gas trying to fix a time for them to quote (yes, quote, not even fit!) for a new one...so I have to waste next Tuesday waiting in between 7am and 9pm... I craved comfort. Big, cosy, bowls of risotto-y, sausage-and-mash-y type of comfort. Not fiddly little plates of dainty stuff.But off I set for Salt Yard nonetheless, as I hate messing friends around by changing arrangments. It was chucking it down with rain. After about 3 minutes it became clear the boots I thought were waterproof were in fact totally broken across the sole. Arrived at Salt Yard at 7.15, wet feet and all - and luckily there was a table. We shared some safron and seafood arancini, courgette flowers with goats cheese and honey, and scallops. My friend also had some chorizo with peppers which I couldn't try as I am allergic to chilli. The arancini tasted solely of saffron, I couldn't detect any of the seafood which was apparently inside, but they were very small, so I might have missed it. The scallop was fine, but not very hot, and the cauliflower puree didn't really add anything. I liked the courgette flower. We seemed to have finished eating by 8.30 and I didn't like any of the desserts on offer - so merely to prolong the evening, I ordered some mint tea I didn't really want (the waitress said the decaff coffee was not very fresh) and a cantucci I didn't like (wierd aniseed taste). The bill came to £20 each which seemed a lot for what wasn't really a lot of food, and I'm not exactly full.So I am not really sure who Salt Yard is for. The food was good, with lots of interesting choices, but don't go when you're hungry. Or when you've just been landed with a £2,000 bill for a new gas boiler.

Y5xNbNkljrDMvhDHDrIfhw.text: Check out my blog for photos and more:hungryinlondon.com/2011/…  I tremendously enjoyed some of the dishes I had at the Opera Tavern earlier this month and was therefore keen to try its two older siblings Salt Yard and Dehesa. All three restaurants serve a range of charcuterie and tapas-style dishes with strong Spanish and some Italian influence. While dishes like the pork and foie gras burger at the Opera Tavern were amongst the best things I have eaten in the past few months and showed signs of true genius, Salt Yard was a disappointment in comparison. All the non-cooked dishes such as Serano ham and cheese were highly enjoyable, but Salt Yard was let down by the dishes that required preparing.Padron Pepper (4.25) We nibbled some Padron Pepper (4.25) while choosing the wine and these were good and nicely seasoned, if a bit too oily for my liking. Also from the 'Bar Snack' menu was the Confit Tuna with Crostini (3.50) which was for me a rather unpleasant dish. The tuna was tough and far too salty but could possibly have been saved by proper Italian style crostini. Sadly, the bread that came with the dish was sliced too thinly and was much too hard, resembling bread crisps. You might feel differently, but I realised at this point that I am not very keen at all on bread crisps. Much better was the moist and flavoursome 18 months cured Serano Ham (8.40) served in thin slices (at this occasion thin slices were a good thing). Similar to the Opera Tavern, the bread had to be ordered separately. The only choice of bread was the Chargrilled Country Style Bread with Olive Oil OR Aioli (2.55) which I quite liked, but which was categorically rejected by dinner companion. All he had to say was 'This bread is crap'.18 months cured Serano Ham (8.40)Confit Tuna with Crostini (3.50) From the main tapas menu we tried the Escabeche of Mackerel, Fennel and Broad Beans (7.25). Not exactly a dish to write home about as the mackerel was too dry (the kind of 'sticking between your teeth' dry, I am sure there is a good word for this in English, could anyone tell a poor foreigner what it is?). It resembled pickled herring, only pickled herring is better. The Asparagus, Broad Beans, St. George's Mushrooms and Peas with Summer Truffle and Shallot Dressing (7) sounded so delicious, it was let down however by several flaws in its execution. Asparagus and beans were overcooked, the chef was very stingy on the asparagus and we only got the back bits (I mean really, the nice thing about asparagus are the heads, right?) and the dressing was basically non-existent. The slices of summer truffles didn't taste the least bit of truffles either, so I had to satisfy my truffle craving with the dessert in the form of Truffle Pecorino (6.25). I love this cheese, and the piece served was generous.Escabeche of Mackerel, Fennel and Broad Beans (7.25)Asparagus, Broad Beans, St. George's Mushrooms and Peas with Summer Truffle and Shallot Dressing Salt Yard is not a bad place at all and I would surely go back there for some charcuterie, cheese and beautiful Spanish red wine. The atmosphere is buzzing and the crowd is young(ish) and relaxed. If I fancy cooked Spanish food however, my choice shall be Opera Tavern. Have a mentioned that they do amazing pork and foie gras burgers there??? Now I am wondering whether I should bother trying Dehesa or go back to Opera Tavern straight away. Any thoughts?

RCede8iWlDAj6JbXU3qzsg.text: The pork belly with white beans was a great dish and so was the zucchini flower.  Everything else was okay.  I'm probably being a little tough - my standards were set high given I just got back from Barcelona.  My biggest gripe was that they charged 30 quid for each pitcher of sangria - that was high way robbery.

N_-Ta82YGv-paxBluxHiAQ.text: I had a Mega Meal here. The waiter warned us we'd over-ordered, but then accidentally brought something we cancelled, by which time we'd added patatas bravas, but the food was so good the patatas were the only things that didn't get finished!The courgette flowers weren't quite as good as I'd expected, not much cheese, but still a nice dish. From the fish section, we ordered the soft shell crab and squid, both things I always love and really enjoyed. Far from being rubbery, the squid had a refined flavour. Meat wise we got the beef which was quite delicate and the jamon croquetas with manchego. I've found croquetas to be a bit disappointing at times, but these were excellent.The highlight for me was the truffled macaroni cheese, cep and truffle arancini, and gnocchi with girolles. There's a general theme there! Rich, creamy, sensational food. The food of dreams. It was so good. You have to try it.Service was pretty efficient, we were left alone quite a bit at the beginning and end of the meal but the food once ordered came out quickly. Only thing was a couple of times plates were taken when they still had sauce I needed for dipping!We were tucked in a table at the back which was nice because we had more space and less bustle. You do need to book in advance, preferably by a few days.

fCZg1Zd3C8HVIqJ4Zs_sqg.text: Good high-end tapas, but no flavors that wowed us. The presentation was we-done and the service was great too.  But there were no tastes that wowed. All good, but nothing popped. Highlight: The cheese plate of manchego was the best flavor-wise. Also the croquettes were done nicely. Lowlight: frites bravas were just English chips with paprika on them and sauces that weren't hitting the flavor mark as you'd find in Spain. A lazy attempt at this simple dish. Overall I'd say it was a good lunch but pricey for what it was. Also the bench seating is sloped down or something and gave me a massive backache.

F3uJ2OcNXIuvRoQ8sJY_dg.text: I really enjoyed this place, affordable, great meats, great wine selection, overall a great experience. I had the truffled mac & Cheeseassorted meats and cheesesand lots of wineI forget what else we ordered as I've been there a couple times and it had been awhile. A solid place. Go, taste, bebir!

v9UCuQ3gqAJucRdBCGbNRw.text: Actually 3.5 stars.  I visited Salt Yard for a late lunch recently.  Of the 3 dishes I had, the squid and chorizo dish was great, the slow-cooked octopus and potato dish was lacking in flavor, and the quail and ham dish did not seem to be well thought out in terms of flavors (I think using figs vs. grapes may have been preferable in terms of balancing out the ham).  I will say that I had a nice glass of sparkling rose (or prosessco rosato), but I don't think that made up for the plates I found middling.  I could say that perhaps I ordered the wrong thing, but, on a menu that is limited, should there really be a wrong thing?As far as ambience, Salt Yard is quite cosy, which was great at 2 in the afternoon, but could be a bit claustrophobic when it's busy.Earlier this year, I stood in line at Barrafina for an hour before being seated around a counter in a much smaller environment, and I enjoyed that experience to Salt Yard.

74YnxBUg7_A16QqpWuXQ6A.text: As a Tapas lover, this place is excellent in providing traditional tapas with an Italian twist (there's even some kind of macaroni cheese there).Rather than going down the traditional road and ordering wine, why not get some of the delicious herbal teas - they have a good range and you get a free refill.Friendly and relaxed atmosphere with excellent food!

EbWlJJVVa05BVke4T-gHyw.text: Cozy place but cramped.  Food rather bland and overpriced.  Ended with the classic tortilla which was dry and needed lots more seasoning.  The chefs kept coming out to trim off some jamon iberico, but then kept eating it in front of all to see.

O-axol3qRL6WN3BlMm5fAA.text: Lately everywhere I eat either serves tapas or mezze.   You will start to notice a trend in my reviews.  I really love food that you can share with friends.    This was the first of 3 tapas restaurants I ate in over one gluttonous, but very satisfying weekend, and Salt Yard is definitely up there.  We booked as we were advised to and I'm glad we did.  The place was packed and it is easy to see why.  The food here is fantastic and really interesting.  We gorged ourselves on Jamon Croquetas, Slow cooked pork cheeks, Duck Arancini and Patatas Fritas with Bravas Sauce and Alioli and it would be hard to pick a favourite, although if I had to the pork cheeks really were sublime.  We also indulged in a plate of Serrano ham, selection of breads, olives and Chorizo.  I'm sure you get the picture - we ate a shedload of seriously delicious food.   We also had a few bottles of wine recommended by our lovely and attentive waiter.All in all we had a terrific night here and I for one cannot wait to go back.  Do yourself a favour and make a date with Salt Yard - you will not regret it!

SqT6FvTmsnRk8UHMpuV0pA.text: "I think the beef changed my life"Randomly found this place when looking for a late night dinner. Most of the other kitchens in the area closed around 10pm, but not this place!It's a tiny restaurant lover two floors, the ground floor has a small bar and open kitchen where you can see them cracking away at the charcuterie etc, we got a table, but next time I'll sit at the bar cos then you can watch them in action. The tables are quite tight together, which made things a bit awks when the girl next to us started to bulb her eyes out!The food really was top notch, fried squid was heavily salted, but light and crispy. We also had their version of patatas bravas, a bit more like home made fries, with aioli and a separate tomato sauce. The potatoes were damn near perfect, slightly crispy around the edges, but sweet soft and fluffy in the middle. Truffled macaroni was a bit odd, the cheese sauce was too thin and they obviously used truffle oil as opposed to proper truffles, at £8.50, for a small(ish) dish, I expected more. We also had the most amazing beef high, a bit like warm carpaccio, on a bed of lentils which was a complete taste sensation. I think the beef changed my lifeService was snappy, as expected, no complaints.

0SAQ63AdDIv0vi3y5Musmg.text: This whole area has so many restaurants and after walking around checking out all the menus, we decided on this place. There are four small tables outside and then lots of seating inside on two floors. A simple menus with some very nice choices. We ordered the lamb, baby squid, and courgette flowers. The honey really complimented that dish. There were a few other dishes and then for dessert we had the churros with chocolate sauce and biscotti with a glass of dessert wine for dipping. Both were nice. I don't think the menu online has all the dishes they serve. What made the dinner memorable was Helena Bonham-Carter sat next to us for about a minute with her friend. They looked at the menu, laughed historically and then left. What was that about I will never know.

oa_He16ovUrmqAFCUI2azA.text: I'm not sure if I would call this tapas, some of the portions were quite big and could easily be mistaken for a maincourse. The food was ok but some of the dishes lacked salt and where kind of flat. We had to pay for bread even though it was offered in the beginning like it was free. I ordered a "black russian" which consists of two components but was denied because it "was not on the meny". Over all an OK restaurant, certainly not the higlight of our stay here.

piAYf8lySXuJB137hVIfMQ.text: Phenomenal tapas. I highly recommend the croquetas, pork belly, duck arancini, beef tartare, courgette, baby squid, and the tortilla. Amazing quality ingredients and lovely display. Still liked the octopus but there was too little of it; more potato than anything else. We got the red wine and that went perfectly with our selections. The restaurant is small and intimate... service was great. We finished the night by trying the ricotta dumplings, chocolate fondant and homemade cantucci. My favourite was surprisingly the first one, they were like fried sweet donuts!

CkMDLz8xVvsxMnbMSfvOXw.text: You want to treat yourself and your date with some fine wine and tapas in a cozy atmosphere? Salt Yard in the Fitzrovia neighborhood is a small two-level restaurant with candle light tables that create a very intimate setting. Great for both date nights and business dinners, this place is busy every night - reservations highly recommended.Starting with the wine, you won't be disappointed. Salt Yard has Spanish and Italian wines on the list, from sparkling (Cava Rosado, Prosecco), sherries (Manzanilla, Palo Cortado, Pedro Ximenez), white (Campi Flegrei, Tanca su Contissa, I Frati) to red (Bellamarsilia, Pittacum, Cerasuolo), with prices from £3.75 - £8 per glass or £15 - £275 per bottle. I tried a bottle of Rioja (£23), a very delicious and smooth white.That was good, but much more of a highlight was the food (in terms of quality, not quantity). As a snack, I ordered the "Italian Selection" of finocchiona, salami toscano, capocollo, and speck (£8.75), with outstanding slices of salami. Followed by several plates of tapas (pan fried duck Breast with parsnip puree, caramelized chicory and blood orange, £7.75, and smoked wild mushrooms with olive oil whipped potatoes, free range egg yolk and chorizo oil, £5.75), which was not only beautifully arranged but flavorful and somewhat exotic in taste. A fantastic experience.The service was awesome - very friendly and although the place was packed, very patient. However, I don't recommend going there hungry unless you don't mind spending about £30 per person on the food (starters, tapas, desert) itself.

O1iX-vxbl2Yrcob0xSg85g.text: Lovely tapas with a great selection of wines which comes recommended - found it quite pricey so dont visit regularly however well worth a visit!! Has outdoor seating so you can watch the world go by. Gets very busy so suggest booking rather than just turning up. You can sit at the bar as well! Croquettes were my favourite!

rpOwGkwp1F28naybBaStcw.text: Beautiful tapas!  Like how tapas should be, savour every mouthful for the unique and intriguing flavours that shine through. Yes it's a little more pricey than your standard traditional Spanish tapas but the ingredients are top class and you can see and taste the care given into each little dish.  Strangely a bit quiet when I went and as such this along with the decor made the experience less casual and more formal than how tapas traditionally is, but that's a minor point and probably reflects the quality of the food, and protagonists more about me preferring to bum it out.

Ti6k16v0rwELvoxewOkPTQ.text: i had been wanting to go here for ages, so one rainy thursday night, Eamon B and i decided to try and grab a quick bite. Despite the packed entryway we were seated right away. I warned them "i have to leave in an hour." and they were amazing in getting everything and still leaving us time for dessert!the food.amazing.really. Venison Carpaccio.Seared Tuna with tarragon.Baby Squid with Chorizo (put Chorizo on anything and i'll love you.).Truffled Mac&Cheese (hello foodgasism).Cured Meats.Almond Milk Panacotta.and more. freaking awesome.The decore, however, needs alot. This place, for all of its mindblowing food, didnt have any soul, any actual personality. It felt like a corporate hotel, or try hard place that didnt quite get it. will i go again? sure. For the food. i'll just warn whoever im with to ignore its lack of feeling.

JiTI7trZKOcU8XkU_oIViQ.text: Came here with my cousin when he visited London in 2010.Small dining area in the basement where everyone is almost sat next to each other and lighting dimmed that makes it hard to see the food you're eating. However, they managed to turn an otherwise uncomfortable situation into something classy by making the furniture swankier and the decorations cooler. Overall, a type of ambience suitable for its upper-class tapas prices. The tapas were tiny, but delicious. Loved, loved the cured meat (salami?) dish. Same goes for the desserts, we ordered something chocolatey (was it churros?) - really sinful and decadent. (if i can remember this even 3 years later, this means it's awesome)Overall the bill was a bit eye-popping (for the poor student in me), but it was a great experience. If I ever get rich enough to start spending lavishly on food, this will definitely be a regular hangout for me.

IE2NCenwPGEaKfjwgsFvYw.text: What a delightful find this was!My friend and I discovered this place on the first night of a long London weekend and had such a great time I want to recommend it to everyone I know. The charcutuerie in particular was delicious, and the waitstaff was lovely.  This is definitely on my list for future London visits!!

oMF61SbY6MsAhX_RQLFZCg.text: Excellent tapas in London's west end.  Great food and good drinks.  Highlights:  truffle mac'n'cheese, chorizo and churros with chocolate.  These are a must order, but all of their dishes are delicious!Went with a vegetarian friend and he found the vegetarian dishes (including the truffle mac'n'cheese) to be fabulous.Highly recommend!

h_7p099FbdnmPzK2TxOqYQ.text: Great, friendly service and they magically were able to seat us when we showed up on a weekend evening without a reservation. The decor is chic and upmarket with (slightly) more spacious seating than most crammed London restaurants. The tapas were modern style with some unique twists.

0OH-DjMq5KZGJjWFzfLMxA.text: Perfect tapas here for me. I come back time and time again for business lunches and with friends alike.It's always packed, which says a lot, but many a time I've walked in and grabbed a seat at one of the bars. The seats are comfortable enough to do so and you still get the same level of attention, service and a really enjoyable experience. You must, must have the tempura courgette flowers, filled with goats cheese and drizzled with honey. They are to die for. These, combined with some padron peppers, serrano ham (18 months cured, drool...), chorizo, bread and maybe another hot dish - possibly the scallops - make up my ideal menu.Oh, and I also had the most heart-attack-inducing but utterly delicious dessert here. It was a special, and basically (to my shame), it was bread & butter pudding. But made out of pannettone. And deep fried. Then covered in sugar and cinnamon. And served with ice cream.ANYWAY. It sounds horrendous, but it was absolutely unbelievable...

U3FSJB20urRnYlMJ-75hHQ.text: One of those places that's nice enough from the outside, but come in and be greeted and seated and menued. That's when you see it, the wonderful food and drink on offer. What a great cocktail list, and the wines! Every plate or plank we got was so delicious, the cheese's so very satisfying, and the shrimp! So perfect. Come here, eat and drink incredibly well.Enjoy!

FkFA2Xw0mm1ki5-E433dxg.text: Came here while waiting for the owner of the rental place to show up.  My friends and I stopped by with a lot of luggage and the staff was super nice in allowing us to store it with them while we waited.We grabbed some charcuterie and wines, as well as a few additional snacks.  We lucked out as this was one of the best places we found while we were visiting London.  The staff here were always super friendly and very nice.My favorite here was their Jamon Iberico de Bellota.  We came here several times during our Soho stay and the Jamon was by far the best I've had in the area (tried a few other places too and none were as good as here).The second favorite here for me was the Courgette Flowers Stuffed with Goat's Cheese and Drizzled with Honey.  This was recommended by the staff and boy was it delicate and delish!  I don't even like goat cheese, but it was a perfect pairing.We tried pretty much their entire bar menu of snacks, and I preferred the Italian charcuterie over the Spanish.  Personal taste though.  My friends really liked the Padrón Peppers, tough it tends to be very salty around the end.Most of the wines we tried here were very enjoyable.  The staff knows their stuff so ask if you're not sure what you prefer.  This was definitely a find, and as London seem to have less of a Yelp presence, we got lucky on stumbling onto this place which was just around the corner from where we were staying.  Definitely my favorite restaurant when I was in Soho.Would come again when I'm in the area!

D4Y7uXiSq0oempsine9gMg.text: Popped in here for a quick happy hour. Small bites were tasty, wine was great, ambiance was cute and staff was super nice. Would definitely recommend.

7XQBK5bqn6m4HjLfL76zzg.text: We arrived after the theater. .they were getting ready to close but we got a order in ...staff very friendly and food amazing!

ObXpFFIZyyfwLdzgzEtaOg.text: A friend brought me here, as we were looking for a light dinner. Salt Yard was cozy, clean, refined, and just everything you could want on a nice evening out. The host greeted us and sat us right away. It was decently busy for a Wednesday night,We ordered a couple drinks, the baked hake with steamed mussels, slow-cooked octopus, the grilled flat iron special, and the mac and cheese. First of all, the presentation of each dish was beautiful! I was so consumed by the food, I forgot to take pictures. The hake was probably my favorite, it was cooked to perfection. The mac and cheese was very cheesy, and since it was brought out towards the end, I simply didn't have the appetite for it. Four plates to share between two was just right. Overall, a lovely spot for dinner!

jNe3IxNIfTPHdMkfrh4cqA.text: Not the cheapest place in this part of London, but a nice small place, with good small plates and a great wine selection.

XTIJomXbdgpOhi69imRIFg.text: We stumbled upon this place while wandering around London on our only 24 hours in the city. The staff was incredibly welcoming and the food was spectacular.

N-lJ1Cvsex-nkF56rvikMQ.text: loved it.  Service was very good, and there was plenty of food.  Wouldn't get the mac & cheese again, but otherwise, it was wonderful.  a good sleek experience.

afnLuMZMPylYIw1t56jvaA.text: Three things:1. Chewest lamb money can buy2. Over salted food3. Waitress who tries to explain to foreign looking people what tapas are.

KV6G5o4eWPGAWbBMUDeLgw.text: Came here on a Sunday while roaming around London after just having landed from the States. So I was sleepy, but with boosts of caffeine, I toughed it out and glad I did because it made me stumble upon Salt Yard.They have a fantastic £20 set menu for lunch: a starter, a main, and a dessert. This is real food prepared by a talented chef, so in Central London I'd call that a borderline steal.My brain wasn't functioning properly, so I cannot describe exactly what I had, but I know my starter was a modern take on a croqueta that had pork belly, I believe, and was complimented with some fresh and crisp vegetables. My main was a duck dish. (I've posted a photo of it.)Not too surprising, I recall the dessert was a carrot cake foundation with other accoutrement, and it was excellent.The wine list is largely Spanish and it covers all price points. We had a nice Ribera del Duero.I don't frequent London like I used to, so when I travel (and return to cities), I like to try new places, but I would strongly consider coming here again because the food was very, very good.

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Duck and chorizo

D6Ie4erx4-OWEfL0Aoe1Zg.text: Really amazing vegetarian small plates. I'm not sure if I would call this tapas - the portions are actually quite big not exactly Spanish. The baked polenta was average, but the mushroom and chard topping was lovely. I would definitely recommend the truffled macaroni and cheese and the courgette (zucchini) flower. Both were fantastic!

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Baked polenta with mushroom and chard
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Truffled mac and cheese
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Arancini

42TIO6DG74NARHdvgh6Oaw.text: Food was spectacular. Amazingly tasty and perfect size. We went there for a team lunch - 8 people, tried at least 15 different tapas and all was delicious. I especially loved their special and fish&seafood. Highly recommended!

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom

183PnDfAOIWRFkxjAz1kEQ.text: Been here too many times to count! It's my go to restaurant for entertaining both clients and impressing friends!The staff are super friendly and never fail to squeeze you in one way or another. The food is always delicious and changes regularly. Yes there are the staples like pork belly on white beans and the fennel salami charcuterie platter. But always something fresh and different such as the unforgettable scallop carpaccio I had over two years ago. Even the story is lovely in that the couple who started the restaurant one being Italian and the other Spanish so they decided to make a fusion tapas menu. You can't write this stuff!If you find yourself in the Charlotte St. area then do yourself a favour and go check it out!

0MF0s5EH1q8vKSXnpRH6Ug.text: I finally managed to venture my way to Salt Yard with their fantastic Bank holiday offer where they were offering a staggering 50% off food during lunch. As much as we enjoyed our lunch the place lacks that charm it has in Ember Yard. It was very closed in, a long bench seating where you share among other customers but with your own small individual table. You also have the choice to sit around the bar. I suppose they try and fill the place with as many seating as possible to avoid people queuing but in the end you lose out on the nice relaxing vibe like you get in their sister branch, Ember Yard which I love. It just lacks space and privacy.Food wise it was great but not extraordinary with some dishes better than others. Most of the tapas were done well but the flavours and textures did not amaze me as much as my first visit to their sister branch Ember Yard.Saying that I was very impress with their Spanish Selection Charcuterie which was very skillfully cut, thin and juicy. They were cured very right to the palate, salty but not overwhelming so the flavours could be enjoyed with the chorizo being my favourite with the punch of sweet spice  They particularly went well with our Spanish cheese selection, paired very well with a sweet compliment such as strawberry jam with a good mix of the more pungent variety, nutty and creamy.As a side we also ordered Chargrilled Flat Bread with Homemade Butter which came warm and fluffy with a nice light herby butter which I wish they could be more generous with as it was lovely and creamy with a very low melting point so it spread along the bread as soon as it touched it. The quail eggs were cooked perfectly, easy to peel, light and tasty. And  the almonds roasted nicely, crunchy and salty. Off the tapas menu we started with the Salt Cod Croquetas which were good and crispy on the outside, stuffed generously with chunky pieces of fish. It could have been more creamier but that was resolved by the light refreshing bravas sauce was a lovely addition as it lifted the sweetness and added moisture in the dish.Next came my all time favourite of the Salt Group chain, the courgette flower stuffed with Goat's Cheese and drizzled with Honey. In fact it was so good my boyfriend nearly cried when the plate got taken away before he could lick the honey off the plate clean. It was just that combination the crispy light batter, creamy pungent goat cheese, sweet warm honey against the savoury courgette flower that made this dish amazing. Sadly it doesn't come cheap, £4.50 for one and we had two to share, The Slow Cooked Octopus were incredibly tender and citrusy. They were a bit over generous with the olive oil which I felt wasn't needed and it was also let down by the ratte potatoes which were under seasoned and bland. It seems like the flavours did not seep through.I also was a bit disappointed with the tortilla which didn't have the oozy effect I was after. I had high expectations for this dish. I suppose it is a preference but I also found this dish a bit bland and could have been more richer. I felt a bit of moisture could have made the texture of potatoes and egg a little less dense and stuffy. My least favourite fish had to be the Roast Loch Duart Salmon,Mussel and Saffron Risotto. As nice as the salmon was, perfectly cooked I found the dill in the risotto way too overpowering, taking over all the other delicate flavours. The risotto was also too saucy and lost it's al dente texture. What a shame for such a wonderful cooked fish with it's crispy skin and flakiness.  We ended with a light finished of Duck Arancini with Mozzarella, Squash Purée and Toasted Pumpkin Seeds. i wasn't sure if i wanted it light as the mozzarella wasn't very apparent. It lacked that stringy cheese and creamy texture I was after but instead had a more healthier wholesome texture to it. Tasted very average to me with the flavours not really coming through, especially the duck which can be very flavoursome. After the meal I felt very happy that we had the 50% off or otherwise the outcome could have been even more disappointing. I just feel I could have better tapas at a more local Spanish restaurant and the prices would have been the same with what we paid. It was also very crammed, little space and lacking something in it's decor although it may have a better atmosphere in the evening. Still I very much prefer Ember Yard being their sister, better food and decor. But I do understand their menu changes seasonally so things can potentially change.

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Classic Tortilla
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Roast Loch Duart Salmon,Mussel and Saffron Risotto
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. Slow Cooked Octopus, Ratte Potatoes, Lemon, Chilli and Capers

3l8YC5hJS1fFD9IJMPiplg.text: Had an enjoyable evening out here, but you have to be really in it for the food. To be honest, at a certain price point one wonders what one is paying for... every dish was exceptionally tasty, but even to share with a party of four it was difficult. Couldn't help but be painfully conscious that every small mouthful was about £4.Anyway, if you're not that hungry or have the deep pockets, you'll be happy with the flavours. Perhaps just not for me.

BOW3l8rNy9uV_6Y0kACj1A.text: Seriously, one of my favourite tapas restaurants in London. They're usually busy, but not overwhelmingly so and they take reservations, unlike most other tapas restaurants in the area. Plus one for Salt Yard.The menu is simple and classic, but they do it well. On my most recent visit, we had the patatas bravas, chorizo skewers, diver scallops (heavenly!), pork belly, and courgette flowers. All were delicious - our faves being the scallops and the chorizo - and we were stuffed by the end of our meal. I've got to say, the Salt Yard group in general does chorizo well... at a separate occasion at a bbq food festival, I got to try their pork and chorizo burger and it was absolutely amazing - the combination of chorizo and pork with whatever seasonings they used worked incredibly well and if I could've, I would've had a second. Wish it were on the menu here!

photos.caption: Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. scallops
Photo of Salt Yard - London, United Kingdom. chorizo skewers

XbsOZCmqrmtpOX3ViMr4ag.text: The standout dish was the Chargrilled Ibérico Pressa, Roast Cauliflower with Spiced Cauliflower Purée & Smoked Almond Migas (£10.50), which comes pink and is pure melt in the mouth gorgeousness.I also really enjoyed the Sautéed Chorizo and Baby Squid with Braised Chickpeas & Squid Ink Dressing (£7.50). Chorizo with anything is great but especially squid and octopus and let's face it, when was the last time you have a squid ink dressing?The Salad of Burrata with Steamed Asparagus, Slow Roast Tomatoes, Grilled Courgettes & Pesto (£8) was also delicious with it's mix of silky, creamy burrata, pesto and mediterranean veg.

ZsHqkjF4dDtEFggM4QNbPQ.text: Our best dinner in London was at Salt Yard. We couldn't get reservations, but the bar area is first come, first served. There were only a couple of seats left at the bar itself when we arrived...but they turned out to be the best seats in the house! You get to watch the bartender mix drinks and the charcuterie staff cut super thin slices of jamon iberico de bellota (a leg from a pig that grazed on acorns in Spain/Portugal). The bartender and the manager were the nicest people we met. They let us sample one of the mixed drinks when they had a little extra, and even gave us a free board of jamon iberico de bellota when they saw how interested we were when the staff was switching out the legs. Amazing food and outstanding staff! We would go back to London again just to go back to Salt Yard. Highly recommend - and take a seat at the bar!

Xa2W-g2jtBVnGDBZbvUDtQ.text: I decided to go with the Ricotta Dumplings with Lemon Curd and Homemade Raspberry Jam.While they looked impressive and were about the size of a small arancini, the flavor was a little disappointing.  The ricotta center was not attached to the crust so that it easily fell off from the center.  The outside crust was very much like a sugared donut in flavor and texture.  I would have liked to have had a more lemony flavor coming from the lemon curd which was almost lost in the mild ricotta.  The homemade raspberry jam was completely necessary to give the dish any flavor, but was much more of a sauce rather than a jam in consistency.I didn't try anything else, but I wouldn't necessarily recommend this specific dessert.  If you're going to go, I'd suggest picking one of the other dessert options or a cheese plate!

4VAqC-lw8pLVdN1JwrhfGw.text: Delicious set menu, one at £35 and one at £40. We went with the cheaper one and were full beyond belief at the end. The most expensive one may not actually result in more food, it might just be a few substitutions that are a bit fancier, but I'll have to find out next time. You'll need at least 7 people for one of the set menus, but they were very flexible about groups. You'll start with some delicious olives, grilled flatbread (with an incredible accompanying sauce...), cheese and jamon. This will be followed by a couple fish dishes, meat, vegetables, and finally the puddings (if you still have room!). My favorite were the courgette flowers stuffed with goat cheese and drizzled with honey - amazing! Also had some wonderful pork belly. If I were to come back here with just one other person or a small group of friends I'd probably have trouble deciding what to order and what not to as everything was delicious. At £35-40 per person it is a little pricey, but for a special occasion it's pretty reasonable and a great experience.
